title: If Germany had not attacked the Soviet Union in summer 1941, would the Soviets eventually have attacked them? When would that attack have happened? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Soviet Union would never have attacked Nazi Germany without solid guarantees of Western aid, neutralization of Japan, and a necessity for the attack. If the US had joined Britain in the war in 1941, that would have made the Soviet Union safe. Such a development would have led to the situation that Stalin hoped for in 1939–1940: The capitalist powers slugging it out with neither alliance winning a decisive victory, both alliances exhausting themselves, and both alliances emerging from the struggle in no position to threaten the Soviet Union. One other possibility: If the West was willing to pay the Soviet Union’s price for support, the Soviet Union would attack Germany, advance westward against little opposition, and extend the Soviet sphere of influence with little cost in blood treasure much like the Soviet Union entered Eastern Poland and the Baltic States in 1939–1940 and Manchuria and Korea in 1945. So, intervention after a long, exhausting war in the West ending in a stalemate was the best situation for Soviet intervention. I can think of only one exception to the above: If the Axis had gained control of the Near and Middle East, thus enabling it to attack the Soviet Union from the south, also. Then, the Soviet Union would have had to intervene to prevent a serious Axis threat from the south. The Soviet Union would have been better off intervening while Britain was still fighting than after a British defeat or even Britain’s destruction. Howard Lederman
